Our full [rules](https://www.reddit.com/r/Ask_Politics/wiki/rules) can be found here, but are summarized below.  * Address the question (and its replies) in a professional manner * Avoid personal attacks and partisan "point scoring" * Avoid the use of partisan slang and [fallacies](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_fallacies) * Provide sources if possible at the time of commenting.  **If asked, you must provide sources.** * Help avoid the echo chamber - downvote bad/poorly sourced responses, not responses you disagree with.  **Do not downvote just because you disagree with the response**. * Report any comments that do not meet our standards and rules. Comment: For NY specifically, what you're doing when you do that is participating in the state's "fusion voting" system. It does not contribute to their funding, but it demonstrates that you want to vote for a party that more aligns with your beliefs/values without "throwing your vote" out.  Also,the other commenter who said that the Working Families Party is only in NY is flatly wrong, they have chapters in 15 states and are growing.  The WFP funding and growth strategy doesn't revolve around the 5% threshold that you're referring to, but voting for them is a good idea if you care about pushing the Dems left but also don't like the idea of throwing your vote away.
Author: NJdevil202

Comment: The 5% threshold is there National vote total the Working Families party doesn't exist outside of New York State as New York state is one of the only States left that practices cross endorsements  What's far more important for your vote Is not the five percent threshold for federal funding But because ballot access to New York State is determined by what party's got a certain number of votes in the most recent presidential or gubernatorial election
